author: potuz
content: reading that it seems that the condition that the points where you are evaluating the commitment are constructed from roots of unit is a computational optimization, and not a theoretical imposition. So I'm not sure if you are after a PoC or an actual optimized implementation, but in principle you can interpolate a polynomial passing through any 256 points and you can use that scheme.

author: kevaundray
content: yeah you do not need to use the domain \omega^0, \omega, ....\omega^{d-1} where \omega is a 256th root of unity. In the new scheme, the domain is 0,1,...255

author: kevaundray
content: Because the roots of unity form a group and the domain 0,1,...255 does not, the part about dividing on the domain is more involved

author: potuz
content: Yep, so it seems this can be carried out on any curve given any arbitrary set of distinct points

author: kevaundray
content: The scheme sticks to evaluation form for polynomials, but if you want to just do a PoC, you can IFFT to get the polynomial in monomial basis, then have the polynomial commitment scheme be on polynomials in monomial basis. This way might be faster to get going because dividing on the domain is replaced with polynomial division which you can copy and paste from some repo, and IFFT is also something that I think can be copy and pasted
